page.title: 13Carn Barra, St. Levan.
page.content: Carn Barra lies a mile north-westof Gwennap Head and is a superb cliffland of great complexity and beauty. The name{Carn Barra means the 'Loaf Carn'. From the headland itself the cliffs run south-eastwards in a line of great lichen covered towers. Between the towers steep grassy slopes run down to where the lower cliffs drop vertically to the sea. In spring the upper slopes are a mass of flowers, small hassocks of stonecrop interspersed with thrift, sea-campion and purple heather. In stark contrast the lower cliffs are a clean sequence of clean granite walls rising from sea-washed platforms; a remarkable piece of rock architecture about two hundred feet across. In calm weather it looks like some abandoned harbour wall it is so precisely shaped. But no ship could berth here, the run of the sea is so powerful.
